page.title: 21Leisure Facilities
page.content:
In 1987 the Sir Mark Collet Pavilion opened for Football, Cricket, Shortmat bowls, Yoga and Play Group. In October 2010 the Kemsing Heritage Centre opened, to store the Village archives. It is attached to St. Edith Hall, which is now 100 years old, and was designed by G Pinkerton in 1911.

Horse Riding: There are several stables fields and tracks, some for training and some for show-jumping, and some for fun. Riding is mostly for the farmers but there is a riding school also. There are two golf courses which are well-supported.

Sailing: There are facilities for sailing and windsurfing on flooded clay and gravel pits, but these are fairly expensive pastimes.

Shooting: This is popular and caters for many people most of whom belong to clubs.

Fishing: The lakes and flooded quarries provide managed facilities for individuals and several clubs.

Wildernesse Sports Centre: Facilities for squash, tennis etc. are available to the public at evenings and weekends. There are also soccer, cricket and hockey leagues.

Contribution by: Kemsing Heritage Centre Association
